entry.title: Selling projects to leaders
entry.content:
Letâ€™s start with one thing, if you struggle to sell the benefits of a good E-Commerce strategy to your Senior Leadership Team, you should quit your job, as the company wonâ€™t last long. However, there are some ways to enhance the role that E-Commerce can play in your business by getting the full backing of your superiors.

Itâ€™s no secret that Directors and Executives are interested in two major factors; Return on Investment and Client Satisfaction. E-Commerce professionals are very lucky that a well-developed strategy will cater for both of these in bucket loads. Automating your interactions with clients can cut the cost of transaction by up to two thirds, whilst also improving your clientsâ€™ experience of trading with you.

If I could offer one piece of advice, it would be to develop your skills in writing and presenting business cases. There is a lot to be said for taking the time to create a well prepared slide deck with all the relevant stats, expected ROI and time frames. Also, if the recent UK General Election has taught us anything, itâ€™s that we need to fully cost our proposals before presenting them! Nothing is going to cut your presentation to a CEO or President short like not being able to directly answer their question. Do your research, prepare your slides, then present positively and confidently. Passion and exuberance are contagious and a vital part of your armory when requesting budget. Mentoring can also provide valuable input when preparing a business case. Is there someone you look up to within your company or a former boss that you maintain a great relationship with? If so, use them as a sounding board. Sometimes, there is no substitute for experience and great leaders love nothing more than having the opportunity to share that experience to help others.

Returning to my earlier point, Client Satisfaction goes hand in hand with ROI. The former can have a hugely positive impact on the latter if itâ€™s done right. One phrase should be at the forefront of any good E-Commerce strategy; â€˜How can I remove all obstacles to my clientsâ€™ ability to purchase?â€™ We only get two chances to impress prospective clients. Just two negative experiences will lead to you losing the client, probably forever. This is a small margin of error, so put yourself in your clientsâ€™ shoes from day one. Your customers need to be central to your thinking when designing and developing your E-Commerce offerings. Donâ€™t forget that one of your best marketing tools is satisfied clients spreading word of your value. A successful leadership team will value and appreciate this methodology, making them far more likely to buy in to your way of thinking.

You also have one major advantage when approaching your bosses for a new E-Commerce project. Automating client experience reduces the cost and time of transaction, allowing your sales teams more time to be productive. E-Commerce teams typically run very lean and can deliver tangible benefits which are plain for all to see. Clients who integrate their ERPs with your business are also more patient if you make mistakes. A typical integration project can take up to three months (more for a large global client). This isnâ€™t a cycle that businesses like to go through more often than they have to. Treat these clients well and you should be able to expand your sales portfolio with them, over a relationship lasting years.

Ultimately, you need to accept a leadership role yourself by driving E-Commerce within your business. Senior leaders rely on subject matter experts to steer their decision making. Guide them well, then deliver on your commitments!

Before approaching your leadership team with new ideas, keep the below in mind:

Â· Practice writing business cases

Â· Prepare and know your subject

Â· Be passionate

Â· Remove all the clientâ€™s obstacles

Â· Provide ROI

Â· Follow up and deliver

entry.title: From Mechanical Engineering to SAP: My Journey, Challenges, and the Next Step to a PhD
entry.content:
The Spark That Led Me to SAP

It all started with a fascination for systemsâ€”the kind that drive industries, make businesses run efficiently, and enable people to work smarter, not harder. As a Mechanical Engineering student, I was trained to optimize processes and troubleshoot problems. But when I stumbled upon SAP during my Master's degree in Industrial Systems Management, I realized this was the tool I had been looking for all along.

I still remember the first time I saw SAP in action. It was during a project on supply chain optimization, where SAP S/4HANA MM was used to streamline inventory and procurement processes. The complexity and potential of the system fascinated me. I was immediately hooked. The transition from mechanical systems to ERP systems like SAP S/4HANA MM wasnâ€™t just an academic shift; it was a career-defining moment. SAPâ€™s ability to manage procurement, inventory, and maintenance processes sparked a passion for digital transformation in industries that had yet to unlock their full potential.

Why SAP? The Game-Changer in Business Processes

Throughout my academic journey, I always sought ways to make processes more efficient. In Mechanical Engineering, it was about optimizing physical systems; in SAP, it was about optimizing digital systems that connect an entire organizationâ€™s operations. As an SAP S/4HANA MM certified consultant, I dove into procurement cycles, inventory management, and maintenance processes. One of the most rewarding moments was when I applied my SAP knowledge in a real-world simulation, extracting data from SAP and designing workflow processes that mimicked real business scenarios. The experience sharpened both my technical and analytical skills.

But what excites me most is not just the theory behind these processesâ€”itâ€™s the tangible, real-world impact. Iâ€™ve seen firsthand how the integration of SAP can elevate businesses, creating a seamless, efficient workflow that improves everything from stock management to procurement strategies. For instance, during my internship at OCP Group, I had the chance to help streamline their procurement process using SAP S/4HANA MM, which resulted in a 10% reduction in inventory holding costs over six months. This is where SAP truly becomes a transformation engine for businesses, driving measurable improvements in efficiency and cost savings.

The Shift: From Consultant to Scholar

As I reflect on my journey, I find myself at a crossroads. Iâ€™ve honed my skills in SAP and project management, but my academic curiosity is pushing me toward a deeper exploration. This is where the PhD dilemma comes into play.

Iâ€™m contemplating two distinct paths for my PhD:

  1. Exploring the Impact of SAP in Digital Transformation: This would allow me to combine my expertise in SAP S/4HANA MM with my passion for process optimization, diving deeper into how SAP can drive change in the procurement and maintenance sectors. Iâ€™d explore how ERP systems, like SAP, can be fully leveraged to improve supply chain efficiency, reduce costs, and enable smarter decision-making across industries.

  2. Innovations in Systems Management and Reliability: With my background in Industrial Systems Management and FMEA analysis, this route would allow me to continue to focus on engineering systems, but with a heavy emphasis on how emerging technologies like ERP systems, AI, and IoT can improve reliability and reduce failure in industrial processes. This would combine my engineering background with my interest in digital systems and process optimization.

The Tough Decision: Which Path Should I Choose?

This is where I need your help. As I stand at this academic crossroads, Iâ€™m torn between these two exciting directions for my PhD. Should I dig deeper into the world of SAP, expanding its impact on businesses and industries? Or should I return to my engineering roots and explore how technology can improve reliability and innovation in industrial systems?

Iâ€™d love to hear from fellow professionals, academics, and SAP experts. What path would you choose, and why? How have your experiences shaped your decision-making when it comes to advancing your career and academic goals?

For anyone who's walked a similar path, what resources or strategies helped you as you navigated this transition from hands-on application to academic research? Any tips or advice would be greatly appreciated!

Conclusion: The Journey Continues

Every career is an ongoing journey, and mine is no different. From discovering SAP to contemplating a PhD, each step has been a learning experience. With every project I take on, I find myself more inspired to explore the full potential of SAP and its role in shaping the future of industries.

As I continue to seek knowledge and push the boundaries of what I can achieve, I look forward to engaging with the SAP community and drawing inspiration from the diverse experiences shared here. Your stories, insights, and feedback are what motivate me to keep pushing forward.

  • what usage data is collected (meaning automatically collected data about how users use and navigate the system)
